thread.title: Washington Post Employee Accused Of Impersonating Police
thread.title_full: Washington Post Employee Accused Of Impersonating Police

author: Jack Davis
title: Washington Post Employee Accused Of Impersonating Police

organizations.name: washington post employee accused of impersonating police washington post employee accused of impersonating police

text:
Washington Post Employee Accused Of Impersonating Police "... attempting to enforce criminal laws." by Jack Davis March 8, 2017 at 4:16pm Advertisement - story continues below 
A Washington Post employee has been charged with impersonating a federal law enforcement officer. 
Itai Ozderman, 35, of Gaithersburg, Va., was arrested after having been seen wearing a vest bearing the initials “ICE,” which stands for Immigration and Customs Enforcement. He was later charged with impersonating an officer and transporting a handgun in a vehicle. 
Although t he Post subsequently noted Ozderman’s connection to the newspaper, its initial report in his arrest made no mention that he was employed by the company. Advertisement - story continues below 
The Post later reported it had suspended Ozderman. What? #Washington Post employee allegedly impersonated ICE agent https://t.co/4EAUeaRWlP Itai Ozderman, 35 
— anne hillebrand (@annehillebrand2) March 7, 2017 
Thomas DeGonia, Ozderman’s lawyer, said FBI officials are still investigating. Advertisement - story continues below 
Two weeks ago, a raid by FBI agents and a SWAT team in Montgomery County, Md., discovered two M4 assault rifles inside Ozderman’s home. 
Police also found a loaded handgun and a Baltimore County police badge in a vehicle. Overall, the search netted 10 guns, body armor, tactical vests and weapons magazines as well as police radios. 
Ozderman listed his occupation at the Post as an “IT Engineer” and said he had worked there for two years, court records said. 
“All we have to share is that we are aware of the story and looking into it,” said Shani George, director of communications for the Washington Post. Advertisement - story continues below
